Caption: Fig. 1. Example of brushing and linking in the charts used for our study. Quarter 2 has been selected by the analyst in the top middle chart. Data corresponding to Quarter 2 are highlighted in all other charts. Partial bar highlighting indicates the proportion of the data that match Quarter 2.

Fig. 2. Screen shot of a distributed collaboration prototype we devel- oped. Each user has their own work area where they can create charts. Shared parts of collaborators’ workspaces may be viewed by selecting the appropriate tab.

Fig. 3. Four collaborative brushing and linking conditions used in our hypotheses for our study. Persistence also improves comprehension study. In the study, participants saw six linked charts, but here only two and memorability of the awareness visualization [25].
Fig. 4. Box plots of the number of correctly identified common questions in the secondary task (out of 3).
Fig. 5. Box plots showing primary task completion time for the four con- ditions.
Fig. 7. Box plots of perceived distraction for the three visualization types. Distraction was measured on a 5-point Likert scale (1=Not distracting, 5=Very distracting).
Fig. 6. Box plots showing primary task accuracy (number of correct answers, out of 6).
